Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Characterization of the Two-dimensional/Temporal Mosaic of Drop Size Distributions and Spatial Variability (Structure) in Rain
Award.AbstractNarration:
Characteristic scales and structures of precipitation particle distributions have generally been explored over dimensions considerably larger than 1 km, yet for several reasons it is important to characterize their variability on far smaller scales. These include the need to: (1) optimize interpretation of observations made by simple rain gages and disdrometers and the translation of such measurements to much larger scales, as needed for validation of numerical weather forecasts and flood warnings; (2) better understand drop interactions and evolution in a multi-dimensional context rather than just the classical time dependent treatment in the vertical for falling precipitation (as has often been considered adequate for representation of processes including raindrop collision, coalescence and break-up); (3) achieve a more complete description of how radar-emitted microwaves interact with rain; and (4) ultimate connection and perhaps translation of 1-D observations of drop size distributions to larger 2-D domains.

The intellectual merit of this project derives from quantification of small-scale precipitation structures via combined use of a 2-D video disdrometer in conjunction with a networked array of optical disdrometers, through which investigators will calculate pair-correlation functions in rain to derive improved measures of any given precipitation field's horizontal geometry. Disdrometer observations (whose horizontal separation may be readily adjusted) will also allow examination a wide range of distances for possible scaling, self-similarity and functional structures of drop size distributions so as to better connect with remote-sensor measurements of precipitation covering large areas. The over-arching objective of this work is to collect and analyze time-series observations of rainfall over horizontal scales ranging from centimeters (as observed using a 2-D video disdrometer) up to several tens to perhaps a hundred meters or more. Broader Impacts will come through potential contributions to improved flood prediction and monitoring as well as better processes relevant to soil erosion, through support of hands-on student involvement in, and through improved observational infrastructure at an undergraduate institution serving underrepresented groups.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project -- linked with award 1230087 -- endeavored to explore the spatio-temporal structure of rainfall on scales not typically resolved in meteorological study.

Large-scale precipitation measurements are common.  Radars (or similar instruments) are well-equipped to reveal information on spatial scales up to several hundred kilometers, but typically do not retain any information on spatial scales smaller than about 1 km nor temporal information on time scales smaller than about 5 minutes.

Small-scale instrumentation (e.g. tipping-bucket rain gauges, weighing rain gauges, and optical or mechanical disdrometers) do a great job of resolving very localized information about rainfall -- sometimes even resolving individual drop sizes and arrival times.  However, these "point-measurement" instruments reveal limited information about spatial and temporal structures on scales larger than about a tenth of a meter or lasting longer than a few seconds.  Any changes detected over time cannot be unambiguously attributed to temporal changes, since spatial variabillity (or sampling uncertainty) could cause the same change in the instrument's measurements.

In order to study the space and time scales between these two extremes, a one-of-a-kind array of meteorological instruments that measure rain drop arrivals and sizes (called disdrometers) were purchased, calibrated, deployed, and maintained.  This network was deployed at a field location near Hollywood, SC in such a way so as to enable the collection of point-detectors to reveal information about spatial scales larger than the measurement size of each individual detector, while still retaining data at the high resolution achieved by each individual instrument.  Thus, for perhaps the first time a data-set was collected that allows for the meaningful exploration of the spatial and temporal structure of rainfall on spatial scales between about 0.1 meters and 100 meters, and on time-scales from seconds to minutes.

The scales in question are socially important.  In addition to the purely scientific desire to understand these spatial scales to understand precipitation microphysical processes better, it is important to be able to understand the uncertainties and possible errors implicit in extrapolating data from radars to smaller scales or point instruments to larger scales, since existing algorithms rely on intercomparison between the two in a process called "ground truthing".  The "scale-matching" problem is one well known in the atmospheric community, and exploring the scales between the two types of instruments is an important step in helping us decide how much we can trust the "ground truth" process. There are a wide variety of other possble impacts, including a more sophisticated treatment of raindrop-induced erosion processes than currently exists in the literature.

This particular component of the collaborative grant was primarily responsible for the construction and maintance of the array, in conjunction with student traning.  A total of 9 undergraduate students spent significant time working on the project, and we have acquired hundreds of gigabytes of raw data that we have just begun to explore in earnest.

In conjunction with the PI of award 1230087, we have been able to publish and present a large number of studies that have explored particular elements of the data set.  Some of the more meaniingful results are:

1. The statistical structure of rainfall changes as it moves across even a 100 m domain; this suggests that the common practice of replacing spatial averaging with time averaging (e.g. the Taylor "frozen-field hypothesis") may not be valid for precipitation studies on these scales.

2. A non-negigible fraction of small (<1 mm diameter) raindrops fall at speeds exceeding their terminal velocity in still air.  We have been able to definitively determine that this occurs in a wide variety of meteorological conditions, and is not an instrumental effect.

3. Sampling coniderations plague point-disdrometer measurements.  This has far-reaching consequence in using disdrometer measurements to validate radar retrieval algorithms, partition rain events into definitive rain events, estimate rainfall properties from individual detectors, and understand storm evolution.

4. The importance in determining raindrop size in estimating more physically meaningful quantities like rainfal rate depends on the size of the spatial domain in question.  Rain rate is often far more strongly correlated to the drop arrival rate than the mean drop size.

5. Areal-averaged drop size distrbutions often do a poor job of capturing the space and time variability within the area.  Sizeable deviations from average behavior have been oberved on all scales studied in detail.

We have utilized this instrumentation to begin a continuation study in which we plan to push our understanding of spatial and temporal variaibility on sub-kilometer and sub-minute scales even further.
